article.paragraph: The wordChrist(or similar spellings) appears in English and most Europeanlanguageslanguages. It is derived from theGreek languageGreekwordlanggrcΧριστός,Christs(transcribed in Latin asChristus), in theNew Testamentas adescriptionfor Jesus. According to one theory, it is ultimately derived from theEgyptian languageEgyptianwordkheru, meaning "Word" or "Voice" (cognates:logos,chrism;charisma).cite webBrewerWillisEgyptian origin of the word Christhttp://opensiuc.lib.siu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?articleSouthern Illinois Universitycite webPaloJohnMystic giftshttp://www.crcsite.org/egypt.htmChrist is now often used as if it were a name, one part of the name "Jesus Christ", but is actually a title (the Messiah). Its usage in "Christ Jesus" emphasizes its nature as a title.cite bookMerriam-Webster's Encyclopedia of World ReligionsWendyDonigerWendy Doniger20000-87779-044-2http://books.google.com/books?id212cite bookJesus God and ManWolfhartPannenbergWolfhart Pannenberg19680-664-24468-8http://books.google.com/books?id30–31

In theSeptuagintversion of theHebrew Bible, the word Christ was used to translate into Greek theHebrew (language)Hebrewmashiach(messiah), meaning "anointed."cite bookJesus of history, Christ of faithThomasZanzig20000-88489-530-0314cite webhttp://www.etymonline.com/index.php?termEtymology Online: ''messiah''Etymonline.comNovember 19, 2010Christsin classicalAncient GreekGreek usagecould meancovered in oil, or anointed, and is thus a literal translation ofmessiah.

The spellingChristin English wasstandardizationstandardizedin the 18th century, when, in the spirit ofage of Enlightenmentthe Enlightenment, the spelling of certain words was changed to fit theirGreek languageGreekorLatinorigins. Prior to this, inOld EnglishOldandMiddle English, the word was usually spelledCristtheibeing pronounced either asIPAc-eniː, preserved in the names of churches such asSt Katherine Cree, or as a shortIPAc-enɪ, preserved in the modern pronunciation of Christmas. The spelling "Christ" is attested from the 14th century.OEDChrist

In modern and ancient usage, even in secular terminology, Christ usually refers to Jesus, based on the centuries-old tradition of such use. Since theApostolic Age, the use of the definite article before the word Christ and its development into a proper name signifies its identification with Jesus as the promised Jewish messiah.CathEncyOrigin of the Name of Jesus Christ
article.heading: Background and New Testament references

article.paragraph: At the time of Jesus, there was no single form ofSecond Temple Judaism, and there were significant political, social and religious differences among the Jews.cite bookChristianityDonald W.Ekstrand20081-60477-929-2147–150However, for centuries the Jews had used the termmoshiach("anointed") to refer to their expected deliverer.A large number of Old Testament passages were regarded asMessiahmessianicby the Jews, many more than are commonly considered messianic by Christians, and different groups of Jews assigned varying degrees of significance to them.

The Greek wordmessiasappears only twice in theSeptuagintof the promised prince (Bibleref2Daniel9:26;Bibleref2Psalm2:2). When a name was wanted for the promised one who was to be at once King and Savior, this title was used.CathEncyMessiahcite bookJesus the ChristWalterKasperWalter Kasper19760-8091-2081-X104–105TheNew Testamentstates that the Messiah, long awaited, had come and describes this savior as "the Christ". InbiblerefMatt16:16the apostle Peter, in what has become a famous proclamation of faith among Christians since the first century, said, "You are the Christ, the Son of the living God."

bibleref2Mark1:1KJV("The beginning of the gospel of Jesus Christ, the Son of God") identifies Jesus as both Christ and theSon of God. The divinity is re-affirmed inbibleref2Mark1:11KJV.cite bookLord Jesus Christ: Devotion to Jesus in Earliest ChristianityLarry W.HurtadoLarry Hurtado20050-8028-3167-2288Thereafter, Mark never applies Christ to Jesus as a name.bibleref2Matthew1:1uses Christ as a name andbibleref2Matthew1:16explains it again with: "Jesus, who is called Christ". In theGospel of John, Jesus referred to himself as the Son of God far more frequently than in theSynoptic Gospels.cite bookLord Jesus Christ: Devotion to Jesus in Earliest ChristianityLarry W.HurtadoLarry Hurtado20050-8028-3167-2363–363

The use of the definite article before the word "Christ" and its gradual development into a proper name show the Christians identified the bearer with the promised Messiah of the Jews who fulfilled all the Messianic predictions in a fuller and a higher sense than had been given them by therabbis.

While the Gospels of Mark and Matthew begin by calling Jesus both Christ and the Son of God, these are two distinct attributions. They develop in the New Testament along separate paths and have distinct theological implications. The development of both titles involves "the precursor",John the Baptist. At the time inRoman Judaeathe Jews had been awaiting the "messiah". And many people were wondering who it would be. When John the Baptist appeared and began preaching, he attracted disciples who assumed he would be announced as the Messiah, or "the one" they had been awaiting. But the title Son of God was not attributed to John.

The first instance of his being called the Son of God appears duringBaptism of Jesushis baptismby John the Baptist. In the narrative, a voice from heaven called Jesus "My Son". In theMessengers from John the Baptistepisode, inbibleref2Matthew11:2–6NIV;KJVandbibleref2Luke7:18–23NIV;KJV,cite bookThe Gospel of MatthewRudolfSchnackenburgRudolf Schnackenburg20020-8028-4438-3104whenJohn the Baptistwas in prison two of his disciples asked Jesus a question on his behalf: "Are you the one to come after me or shall we wait for another?"cite bookMercer dictionary of the BibleWatson E.MillsRoger AubreyBullard19980-86554-373-9459indicating that John doubted the identity of Jesus as Christ at that time, see alsoRejection of Jesus.

Inbibleref2John11:27NIV;KJVMartha told Jesus "you are the Christ, the Son of God, who is coming into the world", signifying that both titles were generally accepted (yet considered distinct) among the followers of Jesus before theRaising of Lazarus.cite bookChristianityDonald W.Ekstrand20081-60477-929-281

Explicit claims of Jesus being the Messiah are found in the Canonical Gospels in theConfession of Peter(e.g.bibleref2Matthew16:169) and the words of Jesus before his judges in theSanhedrin trial of Jesus.bibleref2Matthew16:13–20,bibleref2Mark8:27–309andbibleref2Luke9:18–209These incidents involve far more than a mere claim to the Messiahship; taken in their setting, they constitute a claim to be the Son of God.

In the trial of Jesus before the Sanhedrin andPilate, it might appear from the narratives of Matthew and Luke that Jesus at first refused a direct reply to the high priest's question: "Art thou the Christ?" Although his answer is given merely assu eipas(thou hast said it), the Gospel of Mark states the answer asego eimi(I am) and there are instances from Jewish literature in which the expression, "thou hast said it", is equivalent to "you are right".The Messianic claim was less significant than the claim to divinity which caused the high priest's horrified accusation ofblasphemyand the subsequent call for the death sentence. Before Pilate on the other hand it was merely the assertion of his royal dignity which gave ground for his condemnation.

In thePauline Epistlesthe word Christ is so closely associated with Jesus that it is apparent that for theEarly Christiansthere is no need to claim that Jesus is Christ, for that is considered widely accepted among them. Hence Paul can use the termChristoswith no confusion as to whom it refers, and as inbibleref21Corinthians4:15NIV;KJVandbibleref2Romans12:5NIV;KJVhe can use expressions such as "in Christ" to refer to the followers of Jesus.cite bookLord Jesus Christ: Devotion to Jesus in Earliest ChristianityLarry W.HurtadoLarry Hurtado20050-8028-3167-299Paul proclaimed him as the new Adam, who restored through obedience what Adam lost through disobedience.cite bookEncyclopedia of theology: A concise Sacramentum mundiKarlRahnerKarl Rahner20040-86012-006-6730–739The Pauline epistles are a source of some key Christological connections, e.g.bibleref2Ephesians3:17–199relates thelove of Christto theknowledge of Christ, and considers the love of Christ as a necessity for knowing him.cite bookThe letters to the Galatians and EphesiansWilliamBarclayWilliam Barclay (theologian)20020-664-22559-4152–153

There are also implicit claims to being the Christ in the words and actions of Jesus.Episodes in the life of Jesus and statements about what he accomplished during his public ministry are found throughout theNew Testament. Trinity-based theology summarily claims: "Jesus Christ was fully God and fully man in one person, and will be so forever."cite bookGrudemWayne A.Wayne GrudemSystematic Theology: An Introduction to Biblical DoctrineZondervan19940-310-28670-0http://books.google.com/books?idThe Person Of Christ529
article.heading: Pre-existence, Incarnation and Nativity
article.paragraph: see alsoPre-existence of ChristLogos (Christianity)Nativity of JesusFile:Sainte-marie Madeleine2.jpgthumb180pxTheAnointing of Jesus, c. 1450.There are distinct, and differing, views among Christians regarding the existence of Christ before his conception. A key passage in the New Testament isbibleverseJohn1:1–18NIVwhere John 1:17 specifically mentions that "grace and truth came through Jesus Christ." Those who believe in theTrinity, consider Christ a pre-existent divineHypostatic unionhypostasiscalled theLogosor theLogos (Christianity)Word. Other, non-Trinitarian views, question the aspect of personal pre-existence or question the aspect of divinity, or both. An example is the Orthodox Gnomic view, which asserts that Christ was, in fact, not a pre-existent divine being.

The concept of Christ asLogos (Christianity)Logosderives frombibleverseJohn1:1NIV: "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God." In the original Greek,Logos() is used for "Word," and is often used untranslated. In theChristologyof the Logos, Christ is viewed as the Incarnation of the "Divine Logos", i.e. The Word.cite bookA theology primerRobert C.NevilleRobert Cummings Neville19910-7914-0849-3141

Christian teachings present theLove of Christas a basis for his sacrificial act that brought forth salvation.Ins:Bible (American Standard)/John#14:31John 14:31Jesus explains that his sacrifice was performed so: "that the world may know that I love the Father, and as the Father gave me commandment, even so I do."cite bookPreaching the Gospel of John: Proclaiming the Living WordLamarWilliamson20040-664-22533-0192s:Bible (American Standard)/Ephesians#5:25Ephesians 5:25then states that: "Christ also loved the church, and gave himself up for it".cite bookNew Testament ChristologyFrank J.Matera19990-664-25694-5155–156

In the 2nd century,Irenaeusexpressed his views of salvation in terms of the imitation of Christ and his theory of "recapitulation". For Irenaeus the imitation of Christ is based on God's plan of salvation, which involved Christ as the "Last Adam"Watson E. Mills, Roger Aubrey Bullard, eds,Mercer dictionary of the Bible. 1998, p. 10. ISBN 0-86554-373-9James D. G. DunnDunn, James D. G.(2006)The Theology of Paul the Apostle.p. 241. ISBN 0802844235He viewed the incarnation as the way in which Christ repaired the damage done by Adam's disobedience. For Irenaeus, salvation was achieved by Christ restoring humanity to the image of God, and he saw the Christian imitation of Christ as a key component on the path to salvation.cite bookTheological turning points: Major issues in Christian thoughtDonald K.McKim19890-8042-0702-X80For Irenaeus Christ succeeded on every point on which Adam failed.cite bookChrist at the Center: The Early Christian EraLisa D. MaugansDriver20090-664-22897-6134Irenaeus drew a number of parallels, e.g. just as in the fall of Adam resulted from the fruit of a tree, Irenaeus saw redemption and salvation as the fruit of another tree: theCrucifixion of Jesuscross of crucifixion.

Following in thePauline ChristianityPauline tradition, in the 5th centuryAugustine of Hippoviewed Christ as the mediator of theNew Covenantbetween God and man and as the conqueror over sin. He viewed Christ as the cause and reason for the reconciliation of man with God after the fall of Adam, and he saw in Christ the path to Christian salvation.cite bookTheological turning points: Major issues in Christian thoughtDonald K.McKim19890-8042-0702-X85–86Augustine believed that salvation is available to those who are worthy of it, through faith in Christ.cite bookAn introduction to the theology of religionsVeli-MattiKärkkäinen20030-8308-2572-X66

In the 13th centuryThomas Aquinasaimed to recapture the teachings of theChurch Fatherson the role of theHoly Trinityin the economy of salvation.cite bookThe Trinitarian Theology of Saint Thomas AquinasGillesEmeryFrancesca AranMurphy20100-19-958221-113–15In Aquinas' viewangelsand humans were created for salvation from the very beginning.cite bookThomas Aquinas' trinitarian theology: A study in theological methodTimothy LeeSmith978-0-8132-1097-1CUA Press200317–19For Aquinas thePassion of Christpoured out the grace of salvation and all its virtues unto humanity.cite bookThe encyclopedia of Christianity, Volume 5ErwinFahlbusch20080-8028-2417-X490

Martin Lutherdistinguished the history of salvationLaw and Gospelbetween the Old and the New Testament, and saw a new dimension to salvation with the arrival of Christ.cite bookSystematic Theology, Volume 3WolfhartPannenbergWolfhart Pannenberg20040-567-08068-484

The focus on human history was an important element of the biblically grounded 16th-century theology ofJohn Calvin. Calvin considered theMinistry of Jesusfirst coming of Christas the key turning point in human history. He viewed Christ as "the one through whom salvation began" and he saw the completion of Christ's plan of salvation as his death andResurrection of JesusResurrection.cite bookTheological turning points: Major issues in Christian thoughtDonald K.McKim19890-8042-0702-X161

Thus understood, the centuries-old English word mas, is actually a shortened form of CHmas, which is, itself, a shortened form for Christmas. Christians are sometimes referred to as "Xians," with the 'X' replacing 'Christ.OEDX
